source.title: M-5860 Time and effort taxpayer spends on an activity as indication of profit motive—hobby losses.
source.text:
Under the hobby loss rules, deductions attributable to an activity not engaged in for profit are limited, see ¶  M-5800 et seq. All facts and circumstances must be taken into account in determining whether an activity's engaged in for profit, see ¶  M-5832 et seq.
A profit motive can be indicated where the taxpayer devotes much of his own time and effort to the activity, especially if it has no substantial personal or recreational aspects. In other words, the taxpayer's interest in the activity must be more than “passing” or “casual.” For example, a college professor's 40 years of professional involvement with dramatic production indicated he had a profit motive for writing plays. But this factor won't favor the taxpayer if he can't explain how the work he performed related to making a profit.
The Tax Court notes that in a large percentage of decisions where time spent was found to be probative of intent to profit, the taxpayers were devoting more than 30 hours to the enterprise on a weekly basis. And, where lesser amounts have been validated as evidence of profit objective, the expenditures have typically been regular (see ¶  M-5862 ) and consistent.
A profit motive was indicated where:
  • taxpayer devoted “nearly all” of his time, “a considerable amount” of time, and “most of” his time.
  • taxpayers devoted 40-60 hours a week to their horse-breeding activity, in addition to having full time jobs.
  • a taxpayer devoted about 40 hours per week to gambling activities (playing slot machines), in addition to the 25 to 35 hours per week she spent running a trucking business. Taxpayer employed a strategy to improve her chances of winning (i.e., identifying and playing slot machines that were likely due to payout), and, after some initial losses, changed her strategy to help her win (focusing on winning smaller amounts at a time, rather than trying to recoup old losses all at once with bigger payouts). Taxpayer also consulted regularly with casino employees to further her gambling strategy, and watched other gamblers to understand what she believed to be slot machine payout patterns. In addition, taxpayer credibly testified that she didn't view gambling as a recreational pursuit, and found no pleasure in gambling (describing it as stressful, tiring, and time consuming). Taxpayer always went to the casinos alone, and while there was focused on winning as much money as possible.
  • taxpayers, a doctor-husband and professor-wife, spent an average of 15 to 20 hours per week on their sailboat racing venture.
  • taxpayer devoted significant time and effort to his gold mining activity. He compressed the 40-hour work week schedule for his full-time job as a field engineer into four 10-hour days, so that he could spend three consecutive days each week mining for gold. Almost every weekend, he left his home on Thursday evening and drove up to 150 miles into the desert to mine for gold.
  • taxpayer devoted 30 hours a week to his jet charter business, despite devoting 50 hours per week to his clothing business. He was involved in every aspect of operations.
  • taxpayer devoted a substantial amount of time working on modifications to his motorcycle and entered several races a year. The fact that he entered fewer races in later years indicated his decision to leave the activity because it was unprofitable.
  • taxpayer worked on his cattle farm seven days a week, and there was no evidence that he endured this physical labor for pleasure.
  • taxpayer, who ran a successful toolmaking business, spent almost all of his free time during the evenings, and on weekends and holidays, raising cattle. A business reorganization that gave his sons more responsibility and control of the toolmaking business allowed him more time to concentrate on his cattle farming. During the years at issue, he worked an average of 50 hours per week on his cattle operation, and only slowed down when his health problems forced him to do so. Moreover, he viewed his cattle activities as “work” rather than pleasure.
  • taxpayer spent several hours daily performing the day-to-day work associated with his horse breeding activity, as well as two and a half days work preparing for each horse show entered.
  • taxpayers (husband and wife) were actively involved in preparing their horses for the show ring during the three years at issue. They spent a substantial amount of time training, showing and caring for their horses, which they didn't ride for pleasure. In one year, the husband spent more than 1,600 hours and the wife spent more than 700 hours on those activities.
  • taxpayers (a married couple) involved in working at the taxpayer-husband's law firm where the taxpayer-wife kept the books, spent more than 20 hours during the week and on weekends working in their horse-related activities. They often performed manual and menial tasks such as feeding and walking the horses and mucking stalls.
  • taxpayer was retired from his previous position and so was able to devote a substantial amount of time to horse breeding and racing activities. He personally visited the facilities where his horses are boarded and trained to inspect the condition of the horses and to consult with the caretakers and trainers. He spent at least four hours a day, six days a week, inspecting his horses and consulting with their trainers.
  • taxpayer with two young children to care for devoted 20 to 25 hours per week to her show horse activity.
  • taxpayer's entire family devoted enormous personal time and effort to their horse-breeding business, such that it was the full-time work of one spouse, the children gave up extracurricular school activities, and one child gave up a part-time job to prepare for and attend horse shows each weekend for eight months of the year.
  • taxpayers' entire family spent considerable time and effort in operating their horse farm. Each family member had specific duties, e.g., the wife would clean the barn and feed and train the horses, the husband would perform routine medical care for the horses and clear and maintain the land, and the children would work several hours a day riding and working in the barn.
  • taxpayers spent only evenings and weekends operating their horse farm, but hired a full-time ranch supervisor.
  • taxpayer, although president of a company that employed 45 people, spent as much as eight to ten hours a day during the haying season on the farm and during the off-season cleared land, did maintenance work, and personally performed or supervised all the farm-related work done.
  • taxpayer spent about 500 hours a year in truck-pulling activities and, through his diligence and devotion of large amounts of time and effort, was ultimately ranked 35th in the nation by a national truck pulling promoter.
  • taxpayer, an engineer, pursued a career as an actor, took acting lessons, retained an agent, prepared a photo portfolio, mailed 250 resumes, joined the actors' guild, and attended numerous screenings and interviews.
  • taxpayer, anticipating retirement and wanting to gain experience in the horse-business, worked 30 hours per week in horse-related activities, participated in the daily grooming and feeding, and bought, sold, and bred horses in the eight years before retirement.
  • the sole owner of a substantial contracting corporation with a fondness for quarter horses, studied everything he could about breeding quarter horses, consulted and retained experienced advisers in the field, attended many horse shows and sales, and studied the genetic background of each horse he bought. Although he had another business, he devoted about 40 hours per week to the horse business and, to save expenses, his wife also worked full time doing the bookkeeping, cleaning stalls, and grooming the horses. His son spent 20 hours per week attending to the horses. Taxpayer and his wife hired experienced trainers, and did whatever they could to reduce expenses and make their horses marketable for sale, stud fees, etc. They devoted far more time to the activity than they would have if they merely derived pleasure from horses.
  • taxpayer, an author, was actively involved in the writing business for 60 years. While he worked full-time for a newspaper, his sideline book-writing also rose to the level of a trade or business. He made $10,000 in royalties in earlier years, and the expenses generating the loss at issue eventually led to the sale of a book for $35,000. While he derived pleasure from writing, it was also clearly his livelihood.
  • taxpayer, a full-time artist, devoted most of her time to producing artwork and improving her skills. Because of her efforts to promote her artwork, taxpayer's works were in numerous exhibitions at museums and art galleries over a ten-year period. She (1) had one-person exhibitions at nine galleries, (2) had her work displayed at eleven public and private collections, and (3) had her art exhibited with at least ten financially-successful artists.
  • taxpayer was able to arrange his work schedule so that he spent only 26 weeks a year on his electrical contractor job and so was free to operate his commercial fishing boat. Because of this work arrangement, taxpayer was able to fish 17 of the 19 halibut openings (i.e., a limited period when fishing's permitted by law) during a five-year period and spent an additional 53 days at sea fishing for black cod during three of those five years. In addition, taxpayer devoted a considerable amount of time to gear repair and maintenance, boat maintenance, developing cost saving devices and researching different fishing techniques and fishing locations.
  • taxpayer, a commercial pilot, devoted all of his free time to his farm. Taxpayer didn't hire part-time help to assist him while he was flying; rather, he structured his flight time to accomplish as much as possible when he was on his farm. Furthermore, after taxpayer retired, he planned to operate the farm on a full-time basis.
  • taxpayer, an attorney who was a sole practitioner in her own law office, devoted substantial time and effort in carrying on the activity. She worked full-time in the law practice, and maintained normal office hours. The taxpayer also spent considerable amounts of time at professional seminars, bar association meetings and civic functions, all of which were intended to increase her professional exposure and to generate new clients. Although the taxpayer spent less time in her office during the tax year that her father grew ill and then died, this didn't demonstrate a lack of a profit objective.
  • taxpayer devoted two hours a day to his tutoring business. Because of a disability, he was unable to devote more time to the business.
  • taxpayer spent considerable time on a gold mining and treasure-hunting activity. He wasn't merely an investor who made occasional inquiry into the operations. He participated in daily operations, negotiated contracts, arranged equipment rentals, and personally transported equipment. In connection with one operation, he spent 5-6 weeks working long hours, watching pumping equipment during a Texas summer. These weren't activities that provided personal pleasure or recreation.
  • taxpayer, a teacher with coaching duties, spent up to 30 hours a week and over 30 travel days a year on private coaching activities. His marriage and personal life suffered. Although he had a steady stream of losses from the activity with only one year of nominal profit, the trend was towards more income, reduced expenses, and more profit potential. His teaching provided a modest income, so the coaching expenses weren't intended to produce tax benefits. The Tax Court found it difficult to label the teaching and coaching a hobby, despite the elements of personal pleasure, because these the activities had always been taxpayer's personal and professional pursuits.
The fact that the taxpayer, a harpoon fisherman, made only 15 and 12 fishing trips each year didn't indicate that he didn't have a profit motive. The taxpayer testified that there were only 15 to 20 days during the season when fishing was worthwhile.
On the other hand, although the taxpayer spends considerable time attending to an activity, hard work alone doesn't establish a profit motive where the taxpayer derives substantial personal enjoyment from the activity.
A profit motive wasn't indicated:
  • in taxpayer's cattle-raising operations, although the husband spent four hours each weekday, plus eight hours daily over the weekend, and the wife spent five-to-six hours each day on cattle-related activities. They didn't work in a business-like manner. The miscellaneous and disorganized financial records presented didn't show that taxpayers expected a profit.
  • where taxpayer went to his cattle ranch only 15 to 17 times a year, spending three to four days per visit, and didn't offer evidence of the hours of labor expended while there or of having hired anyone to run the ranching operations.
  • when the total time taxpayer spent exploring whether the investment (involving his cash investment of $45,000 and indebtedness of $190,000) was a “good deal” amounted to one short phone call.
  • where the taxpayers, who both had full-time jobs, spent only six to eight hours per year for each time-share unit preparing to rent each unit out.
  • where taxpayer-wife (W) devoted considerable time and effort to taxpayers' horse-related activities (showing and breeding “cutting horses”), including manual labor such as cleaning stables, and attending horse shows most weekends, but the activity had recreational aspects for W who had a demonstrated, long-term (since the age of 14) interest in horses. W's time and effort wasn't so extensive as to be only classifiable as profit-oriented, as taxpayers argued. In fact, a part of W's attendance at the shows was to compete on a horse in which taxpayers didn't retain any possibility of profit. And the unpleasant tasks associated with caring for horses are required regardless of whether the activity pursued as a hobby or business.
  • where a taxpayer, without any experience in horsebreeding or any attempt to gain expertise in the area, bought a mare after discussions with the mare's owner about financial advantages of breeding it. Taxpayer didn't attend any seminars or subscribe to any magazines on horsebreeding. After five years, the only income that taxpayer had was from a sale of one foal and insurance money received on the death of a second foal. Taxpayer didn't maintain any business records or books. Taxpayer also didn't leave his full time job at Southern Bell to spend more time and effort in his horsebreeding activity.
  • where the taxpayers, who engaged in an embryo transplant cattle and miniature horse breeding activity, had little time to devote to the activity. The husband worked full time, including Saturday and Sunday mornings at his veterinary clinic, in addition to being on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week, while the wife had little time for the activity because of her involvement in ongoing public relations campaigns (including a campaign for the husband's clinic) and in other activities of various organizations.
  • where the taxpayer failed to show he spent significant time or effort in conducting his computer consulting business during the year at issue. The taxpayer had established the business after being laid off from his full-time engineering job. But he was again employed full-time as an engineer during the year at issue. The taxpayer conceded that the long hours he worked at that job—between 45 and 55 hours per week—precluded him from providing any consulting services that year. In addition, he spent significant amount of time at home with his family, and also took engineering classes.
  • where the taxpayer, the general partner and promoter of a limited partnership that was formed to conduct oil and gas drilling activities, greatly increased his participation in the activities of the limited partnership shortly after IRS began to investigate it. For the first time, taxpayer began to visit drilling sites and entered into drilling agreements on the partnership's behalf at various previously undeveloped sites. Taxpayer didn't have a profit objective with respect to the partnership during the period before IRS began its audit.
  • where the taxpayer's mother spent most of her time working at the taxpayer's pet store. Although the Second Circuit, in vacating and remanding a Tax Court decision, held that the mother's time had to be taken into account, the Tax Court on remand held that the taxpayer operated the store regardless of its profitability to keep his mother occupied.
  • in taxpayers' organic beef farming activity, where the taxpayers (H and W) were unable to devote the time necessary to successfully conduct the activity as a result of H's outside commitments to other business activities, and the demands placed on W in raising four children. It was only after several consecutive years in which the farm lost money that the taxpayers realized that W couldn't operate the farm profitably without H's assistance. But three more years passed before H withdrew from his other interests and began to devote more time to the farm. The Tax Court characterized the taxpayers “lack of commitment” to the activity as being determinative of a lack of profit objective.
  • in taxpayers' horse-boarding venture, where their own activities didn't go beyond what would be necessary to care for their own horses. When taxpayers moved to the farm at issue, they saved themselves the cost of boarding their own horses elsewhere and had greater access to the horses for their daughters, who were prize-winning equestrians. Most of the work, primarily cleaning stables, was done by the taxpayer-wife, and by other family members in exchange for meals. The fact that taxpayers' clients—the paying boarders—each assumed the responsibility of feeding, cleaning, grooming and providing medical services to their own horses undercut the taxpayers' claim that they were involved in boarding horses for profit.
  • although taxpayers spent enough time in their apple orchard to grow 40,000 pounds of apples, taxpayer (husband) did all the picking himself and didn't pick all the apples. So, he didn't make enough effort to profit from the time spent.
  • Where taxpayer, an attorney who operated two law offices, spent only an estimated one day a month on his apple and timber farming activities, and didn't engage any full-time employees in the activities. Although taxpayer generally went to the farm each week on Thursday and left on Saturday or Sunday, he maintained a second (vacation) home on the property, and expended only minimal time and effort on the farm activity.
  • where taxpayers (H and W), in connection with their activity of selling model railroad merchandise at model railroad shows, collected only $1,100, $5,300, and $13,00 in gross receipts for the three years at issue, and attended only 4, 13, and 24 shows respectively in each of those years. This showed that taxpayers didn't devote much of their personal time and effort to the activity, which helped convince the Tax Court that the activity wasn't conducted with a profit motive.
  • where taxpayer, a full-time quality engineer, who also engaged in a music activity, claimed he rehearsed 8 to 10 hours per week with his church's choir, with whom he performed, and an additional 5 to 6 hours per week by himself in his home studio, but the court didn't believe he devoted that much time to being a musician given that he had a full-time job, also operated a sales business, provided personal care to his fatally ill wife, and raised his children during the years in issue.
  • where taxpayer spent approximately 100 to 300 hours in one year on his stock car racing activity, and held a full-time job at the same time, never missing a day of work.
  • where taxpayer participated in his bed and breakfast activity only when he wasn't at his full-time job as an elementary school principal. Taxpayer had early morning meetings and after-school activities in addition to his official eight-hour workday, and was required to work 11 months of the year. Taxpayer also claimed to be engaged in a woodworking business. The minimal time and effort that taxpayer spent on the bed and breakfast activity indicated he lacked a profit objective for it.
  • taxpayer spent 20 to 30 hours a week on airplanes—time he claimed was related to his aviation maintenance activities. But he didn't establish how much of that time was for clients, as opposed to work on his own Cessna for recreational purposes.
  • where taxpayer spent between 2,100 and 2,800 hours per year on collecting and selling science fiction memorabilia, but even in her most profitable years, her income worked out to roughly only 30 cents an hour. Her consistent losses and the substantial enjoyment she derived indicated the activity was a hobby and not a business.
  • where there was no evidence in the record to show the amount of time taxpayer spent on his Mars exploration research and taxpayer had multiple jobs and was working on a space architecture degree during the tax year at issue. The only evidence as to taxpayer's time and effort during the tax year at issue was that he travelled to two conferences. But he wasn't a presenter at either conference. He only attended for informational purposes.

source.title: M-5825 Requirement for a bona fide profit objective—business plan requirement.
source.text:
Although a reasonable expectation of profit is not required for purposes of the hobby loss rules (see ¶  M-5801 ), the facts and circumstances (without regard to the taxpayer's subjective intent) must indicate that the taxpayer entered the activity, or continued the activity, with the objective of making a profit.
IRS says that the taxpayer must have a financial and economic forecast for the activity, as demonstrated in a formal written business plan. The plan must be realistic, not a “fantasy” profit and loss statement. It must show a short and long range forecast for the activity, and allow for changes due to potential unforeseen and fortuitous circumstances.
The Sixth Circuit held that the correct standard is whether the taxpayer entered the activity with the objective of making a profit, keeping in mind that a small chance of making a large profit can support a profit motive. It reversed a case in which the Tax Court had applied the standard of whether taxpayer had a reasonable expectation of profit. In remanding the case, it said that if the Tax Court found that the mine taxpayer had invested in included an area that would have resulted in a large recovery of gold in at short time, it should hold that the profit motive requirement was satisfied.
The proper test is whether the taxpayer had a actual and honest profit objective when he undertook the venture, not whether he expected a profit. One may start with the sincere purpose of eventually reaping a profit but in the belief that the probability of financial success is small or even remote. That is, the taxpayer does not really expect a profit but, nonetheless, is willing to take the gamble.
Thus, a taxpayer who engages in an activity in which there is a small chance of a large profit, such as a person who invests in a wildcat oil well or an inventor, can qualify under this standard, even though the expectation of profit might be considered unreasonable, and so can a poor person engaged in what appears to be an inefficient farming operation. Still, a vain hope that at some remote day a profit might result is not sufficient to give a farming operation the character of a business.
The Fourth Circuit confirmed the bona fide profit motive standard when it declined to overrule a Tax Court decision denying a doctor's deductions for farming activities and held that the taxpayer failed to show that the court applied the erroneous “reasonable profit motive” standard instead of “sincere and honest” or “bona fide profit motive” standard.
There was a bona fide profit objective, even though the expectation of profit may not have been reasonable, where:
  • a taxpayer, who inherited the farm which he operated, obtained outside employment in order to offset his farm losses and did not operate the farm at a loss to offset his other income. The court said the bleak financial picture of the farm activity was explainable more by inefficient operations than by the absence of the taxpayer's expectation of a profit.
  • an artist craved personal recognition and believed that selling her work for profit represented the attainment of that recognition.
  • a taxpayer invested in a soil treatment process and gave credible testimony that he believed that the process would allow him to realize a fortune. Moreover, this testimony was supported by his diligence in implementing the process. He supplied funds, bought and rented equipment, and solicited accounts and clients.
  • a taxpayer devoted substantial spare time in attempting to develop materials and to market them, although he did not have any business income from the activity.
  • a full-time airline flight attendant had a renewable franchise to market and distribute video cassette instruction programs for use in elementary grades of parochial schools.
  • taxpayers marketed and distributed racquetball racquets under a franchise agreement.
  • partnerships were formed to manufacture, sell, and distribute technology to automatically identify and monitor ingress and egress from large parking facilities. They entered into agreements with X to research and develop this project. The partnerships' expert testified that if the project had been developed as originally envisioned, it would have saved airports millions of dollars and that partnership profits would have been comparable to the partnerships' projections. The court was persuaded that had the project been successfully developed, a sales price of $3 million was reasonable. The partners were not unreasonable in relying on the information provided by X as to the project's feasibility. The court found that IRS didn't prove that the partnerships didn't have economic profit as their primary objective.
  • taxpayer turned down a promotion and quit his job to devote himself to selling solar heaters. He had frequent sales appointments and held solar heater seminars in his home.
  • taxpayer, who was engaged in management consulting, (1) spent more than 20 hours per week on the activity (while also employed for 40 hours per week in another activity), (2) was a member of an industry association, (3) promoted his business by direct mail, magazine advertisements and personal contacts, (4) hired a part-time secretary, (5) kept some business records, and (6) over a three-year period tried several approaches for increasing profitability. The Tax Court stated that the proper standard is whether there exists an “actual and honest objective of making a profit;” whether that objective is reasonable is not the standard, although, in determining whether the requisite profit motive exists, objective facts are given greater weight than the taxpayer's statement of intent. On the facts given, the standard was found to be satisfied, even though the activity was ultimately abandoned after it failed to return a profit after approximately four years.
  • taxpayer worked hard in his attempt to achieve profitability of his three acre farm, was knowledgeable about farming, consulted with government experts, and changed his method of cultivating in an effort to improve production. Some of his difficulty in turning a profit from his farm activity was due to circumstances beyond his control, e. g. his pear trees died from rot and many of his chickens were killed by his dogs and his neighbor's tomcat.
There was no evidence of a bona fide intent to make a profit where:
  • taking into account all costs that taxpayer associated with his plant nursery business, the venture could never produce a profit.
  • taxpayer rented an A-frame house that had no plumbing to traveling evangelists for little or no rent. Although he “charged” $80 per month rent, he actually collected only $20 rent for the year and incurred expenses of over $6,000.
  • taxpayer developed an information management idea which included plans to build an entrepreneurial library and the promotion of his total productive employment system theory. Taxpayer failed to explain how he would raise the money to build, staff, or maintain the library, where it would be located, and whom it would serve. Taxpayer did not prove he had sufficient expertise to develop a library and did not show how much time he spent on this project. Furthermore, taxpayer had no inventory, employees, licenses to operate, separate business phones or records.
  • taxpayers' leased their 80% interest in realty to a Greek Orthodox Church. Previously, the taxpayers had donated the other 20% interest to the Church and had continued to pay liabilities on that interest. Taxpayers' sole purpose in entering into the leasing arrangement with the Church was to enable it later acquire the property. There was no evidence that the taxpayers had any intent other than to help the Church. The fact that the taxpayers sold their 80% interest to the Church at a profit didn't negate the fact that their intent in buying and renting the property was to help the Church.
  • an S corporation, engaged in the recycling business, leased farmland on which it maintained minimal herds of livestock and did nothing to improve the quality of its crop of organically grown almonds. During the three years at issue, the farming expenses totaled $438,663, while receipts over the farm's 6-year existence totaled $25,820. Despite expert farming and financial advice on how to increase profits, nothing was done to change the farming activity. The farm activity was continued for the purpose of using its losses to substantially reduced the income from the S corporation's highly profitable recycling business.
  • after seven years of working on a manuscript, a lawyer couldn't establish that it was likely a publisher would accept it when it was finished. His self-serving testimony and the testimony of his law school professor didn't provide any way of determining the manuscript's potential profitability.
  • a full-time office supervisor was also a part-time singer.
  • In considering the deductibility of expenditures made by partnerships relating to their arrangement with a Brazilian company to research and develop monoclonal antibody conjugates, the Fifth Circuit said that the profit objective test to be applied was whether the facts and circumstances indicated that the taxpayers made the expenditures “primarily in furtherance of a bona fide profit objective independent of tax consequences.” (If so, the deductions attributable to the arrangement would be allowed.) The Fifth Circuit affirmed the Tax Court and denied the deductions because the partnerships had purchased the research projects with the primary intent of realizing tax advantages.
  • In a case appealable to the Fifth Circuit, the test applied by the Tax Court to determine whether partnerships formed to engage in a research and development project had a profit objective under Code Sec. 183 , was whether the partnerships had a “primary” objective of making a profit. The Tax Court so ruled because it found that was the test of the Fifth Circuit as stated in Agro Science, (footnote 4). But the Tax Court found that the Fifth Circuit's test was in conflict with the test applied by the Tax Court in the context of Code Sec. 183 . The Tax Court said that its test for determining profit objective focuses “on the economic viability of the transaction[s] and on the actual and honest nature of the [partnerships'] profit objective.”
RIA observation: The Fifth Circuit's opinion in Agro Science (footnote 4) affirmed the Tax Court's decision in that case without indicating that the Fifth Circuit was applying a different profit objective test than the one applied by the Tax Court. It appears that the Fifth Circuit was not aware that it was stating a test in Agro Science which differed from the Tax Court's test.
  • taxpayer bought a share of a refrigerated container to produce rental income without adequately investigating the feasibility of the plan or the value of the container. Taxpayer had no background in the business, exhibited no interest in following up on his investment, and never had control over the container. The court did not find it credible that in a year in which his income was just $35,000, taxpayer would invest $26,000 to generate a unknown amount of future income. The court concluded taxpayer was motivated by the potential tax benefits the plan offered and not a profit potential.
  • taxpayer, who worked full time, was engaged in drag racing approximately two weekends per month. He testified that any profit from his racing activity would result from the accumulation of “national points” in regional and national “points meets.” Taxpayer failed to adequately explain what a “points meet” was, or what was required to qualify for a national meet. In addition, the Court said that his testimony, that he spent two weekends per month at the race track, was exaggerated.
  • taxpayer, a successful business executive in the garment industry, entered into a professional golfer/sponsor agreement with his son, who had lost his enthusiasm for the garment industry business and, after winning a tournament at a local golf club, felt that because professional golf was undergoing a substantial increase in growth and popularity, it was a good time to make a career change and become a golf professional. Taxpayer failed to make a financial analysis of the sponsorship as a profit-seeking venture or make any attempt to calculate when there might be a return on his sponsorship investment. Taxpayer did not enter into the sponsorship agreement with an honest objective of making a profit, but rather to give his son the opportunity to make a career change and become a professional golfer. The financial support that taxpayer gave to his son under the sponsorship agreement was no different than that of any parent who decides to help a child financially with educational expenses or with expenses for other career-seeking endeavors.
